author: Jeff Parsons
title: Kodi to be BANNED by Intellectual Property Office as crackdown on illegal Premier League streaming begins
text:
Technology Kodi to be BANNED by Intellectual Property Office as crackdown on illegal Premier League streaming begins Consultations have begun that could put a stop to punters using Kodi for illegally streaming live sports and blockbuster movies Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now What is Kodi? User demonstrates how to use movie library Share this video Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Kodi is used by millions of people around the country to illegally stream live sports, Hollywood movies and paid-for TV shows. 
But the Intellectual Property Office (IPO) is set to BAN the controversial software in order to crack down on the practice. 
According to the Hull Daily Mail , the government agency is holding consultations with several groups with "experience of investigating and prosecuting offences related to streaming devices." 
Although the Kodi software itself is not illegal, the IPO is specifically targeting the sale of "fully-loaded" Kodi boxes, which come with illegal video add-ons pre-installed. Read More Over-55s are SIX TIMES more likely to use Kodi boxes to watch pirated video than young adults 
Selling these boxes is a breach of the Copyright, Designs and Patent Act 1988. 
"Internet Protocol Television (IPTV) boxes (also known as set-top boxes, Android TV boxes or Kodi boxes) are small plug and play media servers, originally designed to allow consumers to stream legitimate content (locally stored or legal online content)," said the IPO. 
"Despite the legitimate use of this equipment, software is widely available (illicit Kodi extensions being the best known) which connect the boxes to illegal content through streaming websites, file lockers and BitTorrent trackers." Read More New Amazon Fire TV Stick brings Alexa voice control to your telly 
The government agency added: "Broadcasters and content owners have voiced concerns that, although a range of existing legislation applies to the sale and use of these devices (as well as the provision of illicit content streams), the legal framework does not provide sufficient tools to tackle this growing threat." 
The Intellectual Property Office's consultations will end on April 7. 
The Premier League itself has also taken steps to shut down the illegal streaming of matches. 
It has secured a High Court order that allows it to shut down illegal video streams of football matches on Kodi by blocking access to the computer servers on which they are hosted. Read More Premier League calls time on football fans using Kodi boxes to stream matches for free 
Until now, rights holders could only shut down individual streams, which could be re-established relatively easily, so fighting piracy was like a game of whack-a-mole. 
A Premier League spokesman told BBC News the ruling would allow it to target pirates in a more "precise manner". 
Earlier this year, a man from Teeside was hit with a £250,000 bill for selling "fully-loaded" Kodi boxes to pubs and clubs. 
Malcolm Mayes, from Hartlepool, was found guilty of selling Kodi boxes that had been modified to allow users to freely view content that should be paid for. Read More Are Kodi boxes legal in the UK? How authorities are cracking down on 'plug and play' piracy (Photo: Gazette Live) 
The boxes, which he sold for around £1,000 each, enabled his customers to stream live "pay to view" content - including live Premier League football - free of charge. Mr Mayes falsely claimed that they were "100% legal". 
"I hope this conviction sends a clear message that criminal activity doesn't pay," said Lord Toby Harris, chair of National Trading Standards. 
"I would also warn any person or business selling or operating such a device that they are in breach of copyright law." poll loading
